standard_metadata.standard_description: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

question.content: Amara needs $90$ kilograms of meat to feed her $4$ pet dragons each day. Each pet dragon eats the same amount of meat.   **How many kilograms of meat does Amara need to feed $2$ pet dragons each day?**   kilograms

hints.content: Each dragon eats the same amount.   So an equivalent ratio can show us how much to feed $2$ dragons.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Dragons | $4$ | $\rightarrow$ | $2$ Meat ($\text{kg}$) | $90$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Dragons | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}}\rightarrow$ | $2$ Meat ($\text{kg}$) | $90$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}}\rightarrow$ | $\tealE{45}$  Amara needs to feed $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ as many pet dragons, so she needs $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ as much meat.
Amara needs $\tealE{45}$ kilograms of meat to feed $2$ pet dragons each day.

question.content: Omar has a new debit card. He earns $1{,}800$ reward points for spending $300$ dollars.    **At this rate, if Omar earned $600$ reward points, how much money did he spend?**   dollars

hints.content: Omar earns points at the same rate for each dollar.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how many dollars Omar spends to earn $600$ points.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Points | $1{,}800$ | $\rightarrow$ | $600$ Dollars | $300$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Points | $1{,}800$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}}\rightarrow$ | $600$ Dollars | $300$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{100}$  Omar earned $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ times as many points, so he spent $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ times as much money.
Omar spent $\tealE{100}$ dollars to earn $600$ points.

question.content: Laine reads $200$ pages in $240$ minutes.   **If Laine reads $25$ pages at this same rate, how long will it take her?**   minutes

hints.content: Laine reads each page at the same rate.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how long it will take to read $25$ pages.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Pages | $200$ | $\rightarrow$ | $25$ Minutes | $240$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Pages | $200$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{8}}}\rightarrow$ | $25$ Minutes | $240$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{8}}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{30}$  Laine is reading $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ times as many pages, so reading will take $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ times as many minutes.
It will take Laine $\tealE{30}$ minutes to read $25$ pages.

question.content: Ben the camel drinks tea (so classy!). He drinks $1{,}050$ liters of tea every $6$ days. Ben drinks the same amount each day.   **How many liters of tea does Ben drink every $2$ days?**   liters

hints.content: Ben drinks the same amount each day.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how much he drinks in $2$ days.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Days | $6$ | $\rightarrow$ | $2$ Liters of tea | $1{,}050$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Days | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}}\rightarrow$ | $2$ Liters of tea | $1{,}050$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}}\rightarrow$  | $\redE{350}$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]  There are $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ times as many days, so Ben will drink $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ times as much tea.
Ben drinks $\redE{350}$ liters of tea every $2$ days.

question.content: A fruit basket is filled with $8$ bananas, $3$ oranges, $5$ apples, and $6$ kiwis.  **Complete the ratio.**  **For every $3$ kiwis, there are $4$ .**

hints.content: We are looking for a ratio of kiwis: another fruit.  We need to be able to simplify the ratio to $3:4$.

The total number of kiwis in the ratio has been simplified by $\purpleE{\text{dividing by 2}}$.  |Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Kiwis | $6$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 2}}\rightarrow$ | $3$ ? fruit | $\blueE{?}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 2}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{4}$  So, we are looking for a $\blueE{\text{number of fruit}}$  that we can also $\purpleE{\text{divide by 2}}$ to get $\maroonD4$.

|Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Kiwis | $6$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 2}}\rightarrow$ | $3$ ? fruit | $\blueE{8}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 2}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{4}$  $\blueE{8} \purpleE{\div 2} = \maroonD4$  What fruit has a total of $8$?
For every $3$ kiwis, there are $4$ bananas.

question.content: Sunny's garden has $9$ tomato plants,  $5$ pepper plants, $3$ squash plants, and $6$ pumpkin plants.   **Complete the ratio.**  **For every $3$ tomato plants in Sunny's garden, there is $1$ .**

hints.content: We are looking for a ratio of tomato plants: $\_\_\_$ plants.  We need to be able to simplify the ratio to $3:1$.

The total number of tomato plants in the ratio has been simplified by $\purpleE{\text{dividing by 3}}$.  |Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Tomato plants | $9$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$ ? plants | $\blueE{?}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{1}$  So, we are looking for a $\blueE{\text{total number of plants}}$  that we can also $\purpleE{\text{divide by 3}}$ to get $\maroonD1$.

|Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Tomato plants | $9$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $3$ ? plants | $\blueE{3}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{1}$  $\blueE3 \purpleE{\div 3} = \maroonD1$  What plant has a total of $3$ plants?
For every $3$ tomato plants in Sunny's garden, there is $1$ squash plant.

question.content: A bike shop has $11$ red bikes,  $3$ blue bikes, $4$ orange bikes, and $12$ silver bikes.   **Complete the ratio.**  **For every $1$ orange bike, there are $3$ .**

hints.content: We are looking for a ratio of orange bikes: $\_\_\_$ bikes.  We need to be able to simplify the ratio to $1:3$.

The total number of orange bikes in the ratio has been simplified by $\purpleE{\text{dividing by 4}}$.  |Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Orange bikes | $4$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 4}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ ? bikes | $\blueE{?}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 4}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{3}$  So, we are looking for a $\blueE{\text{total number of bikes}}$  that we can also $\purpleE{\text{divide by 4}}$ to get $\maroonD3$.

|Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Orange bikes | $4$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 4}}\rightarrow$ | $1$ ? bikes | $\blueE{12}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 4}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{3}$  $\blueE{12} \purpleE{\div 4} = \maroonD3$  What color has a total of $12$ bikes?
For every $1$ orange bike, there are $3$ silver bikes.

question.content: A pet groomer gave $9$ baths, $15$ nail trims, $8$ brush-outs, and $5$ ear cleanings.  **For every $5$ nail trims, the groomer gave $3$ .**

hints.content: We are looking for a ratio of nail trims: another service.  We need to be able to simplify the ratio to $5:3$.

The total number of nail trims in the ratio has been simplified by $\purpleE{\text{dividing by 3}}$.  |Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Nail trims | $15$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $5$ ? service | $\blueE{?}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{3}$  So, we are looking for a $\blueE{\text{total number of services}}$ that we can also $\purpleE{\text{divide by 3}}$ to get $\maroonD{3}$.

|Total||Ratio part -|-|-|- Nail trims | $15$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $5$ ? service | $\blueE{9}$ | $\stackrel{\purpleE{\div 3}}\rightarrow$ | $\maroonD{3}$  $\blueE{9} \purpleE{\div 3} = \maroonD{3}$  What service did the groomer do $9$ times?
For every $5$ nail trims, the groomer gave $3$ baths.

question.content: Mabel spends $4$ hours to edit a $3$-minute long video. She edits at a constant rate.   **How long does Mabel spend to edit a $15$-minute long video?**   hours

hints.content: Mabel spends the same amount of time editing each minute of video.   So an equivalent ratio can show us how long it takes to edit $15$ minutes of video.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Video minutes | $3$ | $\rightarrow$ | $15$ Editing hours | $4$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Video minutes | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{5}}\rightarrow$ | $15$ Editing hours | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{5}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{20}$  Mabel is editing a video $\purpleD{5}$ times as long, so she spends $\purpleD{5}$ times as long to edit it.
Mabel spends $\tealE{20}$ hours to edit a $15$-minute long video.

question.content: Elton is a candle maker. Each $15 \text{ cm}$ long candle he makes burns evenly for $6$ hours.   **If Elton makes a $45 \text{ cm}$ long candle, how long would it burn?**   hours

hints.content: The candles burn an equal amount each hour.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how long it takes to burn a $45\,\text{cm}$ candle.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- $\text{cm}$ | $15$ | $\rightarrow$ | $45$ Hours | $6$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- $\text{cm}$ | $15$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $45$ Hours | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{18}$  The $45 \text{ cm}$ long candle is $\purpleD{3}$ times as long, so it would burn for $\purpleD{3}$ times as long.
A $45 \text{ cm}$ long candle would burn for $\tealE{18}$ hours.

question.content: Bao can eat $12$ chicken wings in $3$ minutes. She eats the chicken wings at a constant rate.   **How many chicken wings can Bao eat in $12$ minutes?**   chicken wings

hints.content: Bao eats the same number of chicken wings each minute.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how many chicken wings Bao eats in $12$ minutes.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Minutes | $3$ | $\rightarrow$ | $12$ Wings | $12$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Minutes | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{4}}\rightarrow$ | $12$ Wings | $12$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{4}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{48}$  Bao has $\purpleD{4}$ times as many minutes, so she can eat $\purpleD{4}$ times as many chicken wings.
Bao can eat $\tealE{48}$ chicken wings in $12$ minutes.

question.content: According to Greg, perfect cherry pies have a ratio of $240$ cherries to $3$ pies.   **How many cherries does Greg need to make $15$ perfect cherry pies?**   cherries

hints.content: Greg uses the same number of cherries per pie.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how many cherries we need for $15$ pies.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Pies | $3$ | $\rightarrow$ | $15$ Cherries | $240$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Pies | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{5}}\rightarrow$ | $15$ Cherries | $240$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{5}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{1{,}200}$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]  Greg is making $\purpleD{5}$ times as many pies, so he needs $\purpleD{5}$ times as many cherries.
Greg needs $\tealE{1{,}200}$ cherries to make $15$ perfect cherry pies.

question.content: Each time the Timberwolves score $1$ touchdown, these things happen.  - The mascot does $4$ back flips. - The cheerleaders set off $6$ confetti cannons.  **How many touchdowns did the Timberwolves score if the cheerleaders set off $18$ confetti cannons?**   touchdowns

hints.content: The cheerleaders set off the same number of confetti cannons per touchdown.   So an equivalent ratio can show us how many touchdowns it takes to set off $18$ cannons.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.

For every $1$ touchdown, the cheerleaders set off $6$ confetti cannons. The ratio of touchdowns to confetti cannons is $1:6$.  The cheerleaders set off $\redE{18}$ confetti cannons.  ||| -|-|-|- Touchdowns | $1$ | $\rightarrow$ | $?$ Confetti cannons | $6$ | $\rightarrow$  | $\redE{18}$

Since we multiplied the number of confetti cannons by $3$, we also need to multiply the number of touchdowns by $3$.  ||| -|-|-|- Touchdowns | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$ | $\blueE{3}$ Confetti cannons | $6$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{3}}\rightarrow$  | $\redE{18}$
The Timberwolves scored $\blueE{3}$ touchdowns.

question.content: Finley makes $1$ batch of her favorite shade of orange paint by mixing these paint amounts:  - $5$ liters of yellow paint - $3$ liters of red paint  **How many batches of orange paint can Finley make if she has $21$ liters of red paint?**   *Finley has all of the yellow paint that she needs.*

hints.content: Finley uses the same amount of red paint per batch.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how many batches Finley can  make with $21\,\text{L}$ of red paint.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.

To make $1$ batch of orange paint, Finley uses $3$ liters of red paint. The ratio of batches of orange paint to liters of red paint is $1:3$.  Finley has  $\redE{21\,\text{L}}$ of red paint.  ||| -|-|-|- Orange paint (batches) | $1$ | $\rightarrow$ | $?$ Red paint ($\text{L}$) | $3$ | $\rightarrow$  | $\redE{21}$

Since Finley has $\purpleD{7}$ times as much red paint, she can make $\purpleD{7}$ times as many batches.  ||| -|-|-|- Orange paint (batches) | $1$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{7}}\rightarrow$ | $\blueE{7}$ Red paint ($\text{L}$) | $3$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{7}}\rightarrow$  | $\redE{21}$
Finley can make $\blueE{7}$ batches of orange paint.

question.content: Lucia is making invisibility potions. Each potion requires the following ingredients:  - $2$ eyes of newt - $5$ carrots - $3$ liters of rainwater  **How many carrots would Lucia mix with $16$ eyes of newt in the potions?**   *Lucia has all of the other ingredients she needs.*   carrots

hints.content: Lucia uses the same numbers of eyes and carrots per potion.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how many carrots Lucia uses with $16$ eyes.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Eyes | $2$ | $\rightarrow$ | $16$ Carrots | $5$ | $\rightarrow$  | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Eyes | $2$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{8}}\rightarrow$ | $16$ Carrots | $5$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{8}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{40}$  Lucia has $\purpleD{8}$ times as many eyes of newt as she needs for $1$ potion, so she needs $\purpleD{8}$ times as many carrots.
Lucia mixes $\tealE{40}$ carrots with $16$ eyes of newt.

question.content: Atilio is throwing a party. For every $8$ guests, they make the following snacks.  - $20$ fruit skewers - $16$ popcorn balls - $4$ liters of milkshake  **If Atilio makes $20$ liters of milkshake, how many fruit skewers do they make?**   fruit skewers

hints.content: Atilio makes the same amounts of milkshakes and fruit skewers per guest.  So an equivalent ratio can show us how many fruit skewers Atilio makes with $20\,\text{L}$ of milkshake.  To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply or divide both values in the first ratio by the same number.
||| -|-|-|- Milkshake ($\text{L}$) | $4$ | $\rightarrow$ | $20$ Fruit skewers | $20$ | $\rightarrow$ | $?$

||| -|-|-|- Milkshake ($\text{L}$) | $4$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{5}}\rightarrow$ | $20$ Fruit skewers | $20$ | $\stackrel{\times \purpleD{5}}\rightarrow$  | $\tealE{100}$  There is $\purpleD{5}$ times as much milkshake, so Atilio makes $\purpleD{5}$ times as many skewers.
Atilio makes $\tealE{100}$ fruit skewers if they make $20\,\text{L}$ of milkshake.
